newsitem.title: USA: Texas, California boost U.S. cotton outlook - USDA.
newsitem.headline: Texas, California boost U.S. cotton outlook - USDA.

text.p: Hefty increases in Texas and California accounted for most of the gain in the Agriculture Department forecast of U.S. cotton output, a USDA analyst said Friday.
The crop was forecast for 18.2 million 480-lb bales, compared to 17.9 million bales forecast one month ago.
Analyst Fred Vogel said beneficial rains swelled the Texas crop by 200,000 bales, to 3.9 million bales.
Boll weights in California were "coming in larger than expected," he said, and boll shedding was lower. The state harvest was forecast at 2.91 million bales, up 145,000.

Hurricane Fran reduced harvest acres for cotton in North Carolina to 720,000, a drop of 15,000 acres, according to USDA. The state's harvest was pegged at 950,000 bales, compared to the 1.04 million expected before the hurricane hit.
